Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas observe this body, initially established by what causes?
Namely, relying on the combined essence and blood of the parents to give rise to that cause.
Moreover, by receiving their food and drink, after eating it is transformed and destroyed, gathering and dispersing immediately, returning to the impure lower abdomen.
Then the fire element increases in strength, cooking and transforming it to maturity.

Later, due to the power of the wind, the heavy dregs and flowing moisture are each separated by that wind power - the heavy dregs refer to feces and urine, and the flowing moisture refers to blood - blood transforms into flesh, flesh forms fat, fat forms bones, bones form marrow, and marrow forms essence, and essence then forms this impure body.
Because the Bodhisattva observes this impure body, he then gives rise to contemplation:

This body is a collection of many kinds, each with a separate name and appearance, namely, three hundred bones, sixty fat and grease, four hundred membranes combined, five hundred flesh balls, six hundred brains, seven hundred blood vessels, nine hundred sinews, and sixteen rib bones.

There are also three things that wrap around the intestines inside, dividing the raw and cooked intestines, with sixteen intersections, and two thousand five hundred blood vessel paths penetrating one hundred and seven joints;
Eighty koá¹­is of hair pores are filled with the five sense organs, nine orifices, and seven viscera, and are full of impurities;

There is one scoop of marrow, one scoop of brain, three scoops of fat, six scoops of lymph, six scoops of dregs, the power of wind pervades everywhere, and there is one dou of blood, all of which are filled to the brim.

There are seven water channels that surround it, sucking up various flavors. The internal fire element increases and burns fiercely, causing exhaustion and fatigue. The body's channels sweat. These various signs are extremely difficult to see.
This foul and impure physical form, how can one give rise to excessive attachment to it?
It is like a beggar who obtains what he needs and then discards it;
It is also like a large cart bearing extreme weight.
Oh, all you wise ones!
You should understand the Dharma in this way.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
This body is a collection of various impurities. Foolish and ignorant ones do not understand it.
They strongly give rise to a mind of excessive attachment, like a foul vase that breaks and emits much foul air.
The ears, eyes, mouth, and nose are all filthy substances, which of them is fragrant and clean?
Saliva, mucus, snot, and various evil worms, how can one give rise to love for them?
It is like a fool who takes charcoal, and with great effort tries to make it white,
The charcoal is exhausted, the effort is in vain, and whiteness cannot be achieved, the deluded greed of the ignorant is also like this.
If a person wishes to achieve purity, he cultivates and manages this body in many ways,
Bathes a hundred times and anoints it with fragrances, but when the body perishes and life ends, it returns to impurity.
At that time, the World-Honored One again told the five hundred elders headed by Abhaya:
Elders, you should know that Bodhisattva-mahasattvas who wish to realize supreme perfect enlightenment should observe this body in forty-four aspects.
What are the forty-four?

Bodhisattvas observe the body as extremely foul-smelling, because it is filled with pus and blood;
Bodhisattvas observe the body as extremely fragile, because it will eventually break down;
Bodhisattvas observe the body as physically weak, because it is a connection of sinews and bones;

Bodhisattvas observe the body as impure, because filth and evil constantly flow from it. Bodhisattvas observe the body as illusory, because fools and ordinary beings strongly give rise to false and agitated appearances;

Bodhisattvas observe that the body's orifices and their supports are filled with various impurities, flowing and circulating through the nine orifices and pores all over the body;
Bodhisattvas observe that the body is afflicted by many kinds of distress, as the four hundred and four diseases constantly increase and decrease;
Bodhisattvas observe that the body is a dwelling place, as it is a gathering place for the eighty-four thousand kinds of worms;
Bodhisattvas observe that the body is impermanent, as it will eventually return to the law of death;
Bodhisattvas observe that the body is ignorant, as it does not know the Dharma;

Bodhisattvas observe the body as being like the earth, as it is difficult to level and fill;
Bodhisattvas observe the body as being like fire, as it is bound by attachment to desirable objects;
Bodhisattvas observe the body without being content, because it follows the five desires;
Bodhisattvas observe the body as broken, because afflictions obstruct it;
Bodhisattvas observe the body as having no fixed position, because it experiences gain and loss;
Bodhisattvas observe the body as having no self or other causes, because it cannot be traced to its source;
Bodhisattvas observe the body as racing and flowing in the mind, because it observes various causes with attention;
Bodhisattvas observe the body as ultimately abandoned, because it returns to the charnel ground;
Bodhisattvas observe the body as eaten by others, because it is eaten by vultures, jackals, and wolves;
Bodhisattvas observe the body as appearing like a shadow on a turning wheel, because it is connected by sinews and bones;
Bodhisattvas observe the body as having nothing to be cherished, because it is discarded, leaking, and filled with pus and blood;
Bodhisattvas observe the body as attached to flavors, because it is formed by food and drink;
Bodhisattvas observe the body as laborious and without benefit, because it is impermanent and subject to birth and cessation;
Bodhisattvas view the body as an evil friend, because it gives rise to all kinds of wrong and false thoughts;
Bodhisattvas view the body as a killer, because it repeatedly brings about increasing suffering;

Bodhisattvas view the body as a vessel of suffering, because it is oppressed by the three kinds of suffering, namely the suffering of change, the suffering of suffering, and the suffering of conditioning;
Bodhisattvas view the body as a mass of suffering, because the five aggregates revolve without a master or controller;
Bodhisattvas view the body as utterly unfree, because it is formed from various conditions;
Bodhisattvas view the body as devoid of a living being, because it is apart from the characteristics of male and female;

Householder!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate in this way, all their desires for the body, all their concern for the body, all their grasping at a self in the body, all their attachment to the body, all their accumulation of the body, and all their clinging to the body are completely severed.

Consequently, all their desires for life, all their concern for life, all their grasping at a self in life, all their attachment to life, all their accumulation of life, and all their clinging to life, as well as all their desires for houses, wives, children, relatives, food and drink, clothing and bedding, vehicles, seats, precious treasures, grain and wealth, incense, flowers, lamps, ointments, and all objects of enjoyment, all their concern for them, all their grasping at them as mine, all their attachment to them, all their accumulation of them, and all their clinging to them are completely severed.

At that time, the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
One should know that a human body is extremely difficult to obtain. Do not use this body to create various offenses.
Jackals and dogs take food and abandon it in the charnel ground. In vain, they will only discard this body.
Foolish and ignorant ones are always agitated and disturbed. In this false and deceptive body, they give rise to craving and attachment.
This body is difficult to control and deeply disobedient. Day and night, one suffers without respite.
This body is a wheel of suffering that constantly gives rise to illness. This body is impure and filled to overflowing.
Hunger and thirst follow, deeply afflicting, who among the wise would give rise to attachment?
This body is like the earth, vast and without an owner, and like a bad friend, the foolish give rise to love,
Because of this body, various offenses arise, in the end one will receive all kinds of suffering.
This body is not as firm as vajra, do not because of this body widely create offenses,
The wise should cultivate the causes of supreme blessings, and give rise to pure faith in the Buddha's teachings.
This body will not last long in vain, clothing, fragrances, adornments, and food and drink sustain it,
Because it will return to destruction, temporarily enduring, wrongly exerting oneself in creating, what is the point of passing through in vain?
It is difficult to encounter in a hundred kalpas, the great sage, the honored one, appears in the world,
Quickly give rise to pure faith in the Buddha's teachings, do not receive the utmost fear in evil destinies.
